Additionally, OpenLogicalChannelAck.forwardLogicalChannelNumber and OpenLogicalChannelAck.portNumber shall be present for DSVD.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of PSTN to IP network gateways as defined in modem-over-IP networks?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines the inter-operation of two PSTN to IP network gateways that facilitate the end-to-end connection of V-se ries DCEs over an IP network. The principal characteristics of these gateways are: a mechan ism to allow the transparent transport of modem signals end-to-end, a mechanism to allow the termination of modem si gnals at the gateways and the transport of the data between gateways, the defin ition of a transport protocol, which is suitable to relay data between gateways, and procedures to allow gateways to transition between Voice-over-Internet Protocol and Modem-over-Internet Protocol operation.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The principal characteristics of PSTN to IP network gateways in modem-over-IP networks include a mechanism for the transparent transport of modem signals end-to-end, a mechanism for terminating modem signals at the gateways and transporting the data between gateways, the definition of a suitable transport protocol for relaying data between gateways, and procedures to allow gateways to transition between Voice-over-Internet Protocol and Modem-over-Internet Protocol operation.

instruction: What are the key components of a MoIP operational mode?
input:
Source: Clause 10 Operational modes of MoIP, Clause 15.3 Gateway call discrimination messages, Clause 15.4 Modem relay status messages, 15.4.1 Initialization message (INIT), Clause 15.4.5 CONNECT message, Clause 16 Start-up mode of operation, Clause C.2.5 Text Relay (TR), Clause C.5.2 List of state signalling events, Clause C.5.3 SSE protocol operation, Clause C.5.5 SSE reason identifier codes
Standard: V.150.1
output: The key components of a MoIP operational mode include gateway call discrimination messages, modem relay status messages, initialization messages (INIT), CONNECT messages, and specific clauses detailing start-up mode of operation, text relay (TR), state signalling events (SSE) protocol operation, and SSE reason identifier codes.

instruction: What are the optional modes of operation that may be provided by MoIP gateways?
input:
Source: Other modes of operation that may be optionally provided by MoIP gateways are Fax over IP (FoIP) and Text over IP (ToIP). The procedures for FoIP are defined in ITU-T Rec. T.38. Procedures for ToIP are defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The optional modes of operation that may be provided by MoIP gateways include Fax over IP (FoIP) and Text over IP (ToIP). FoIP procedures are defined in ITU-T Rec. T.38, while ToIP procedures are defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151.

instruction: What are the typical data signalling rates for modems?
input:
Source: 5.1 Data signalling rates
Standard: V.34
output: V.34 modems support data signalling rates ranging from 2,400 bits per second (bps) up to 33,600 bps. These rates are achieved through advanced modulation techniques and adaptive line probing to determine the optimal transmission rate based on line conditions.

instruction: What are the phases involved in half-duplex operating procedures for modems?
output: The half-duplex operating procedures for V.34 modems involve several phases: Phase 1 – Network interaction, Phase 2 – Probing, Phase 3 – Primary channel equalizer training, Control channel start-up, Primary channel resynchronization procedure, Control channel resynchronization procedure, Primary channel retrains, and Control channel retrains.

instruction: What are the mandatory symbol rates for a modem using Quadrature Amplitude Modulation with synchronous line transmission?
input:
Source: c) Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) for each channel with synchronous line transmission at selectable symbol rates including the mandatory rates of 2400, 3000, and 3200 symbols/s and the optional rates of 2743, 2800 and3429 symbols/s;
Standard: V.34
output: The mandatory symbol rates for a modem using Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) with synchronous line transmission are 2400, 3000, and 3200 symbols per second.

instruction: What is the purpose of in-band DCE control in data communication?
input:
Source: In-band DCE control and synchronous data modes for asynchronous DTE
Standard: V.80
output: In-band DCE control is used to manage and control data communication equipment (DCE) within the same frequency band used for data transmission, allowing for simultaneous transmission of control signals and data without requiring separate channels.

instruction: What are the data signalling rates and corresponding hex codes for synchronous access mode commands in cellular systems?
input:
Source: Table 10/V.80  Synchronous Access Mode Command/lndication Bit Rate Values (values for parameters <tx>, <rx>, <maxp>, <prate>) Symbol Hex code Duplex or primary channel data signalling rate <p12> 20h 1 200 bit/s <p24> 21h 2 400 bit/s <p48> 22h 4 800 bit/s <p72> 23h 7 200 bit/s <p96> 24h 9 600 bit/s <p120> 25h 12 000 bit/s <p144> 26h 14 400 bit/s <p168> 27h 16 800 bit/s <p192> 28h 19 200 bit/s <p216> 29h 21 600 bit/s <p240> 2Ah 24 000 bit/s <p264> 2Bh 26 400 bit/s <p288> 2Ch 28 800 bit/s <p312> 2Dh 31 200 bit/s <p336> 2Eh 33 600 bit/s <p320> 2Fh 32 000 bit/s <p560> 30h 56 000 bit/s <p640> 31h 64 000 bit/s
Standard: V.80
output: The data signalling rates and corresponding hex codes for synchronous access mode commands in cellular systems are as follows: 1,200 bit/s (20h), 2,400 bit/s (21h), 4,800 bit/s (22h), 7,200 bit/s (23h), 9,600 bit/s (24h), 12,000 bit/s (25h), 14,400 bit/s (26h), 16,800 bit/s (27h), 19,200 bit/s (28h), 21,600 bit/s (29h), 24,000 bit/s (2Ah), 26,400 bit/s (2Bh), 28,800 bit/s (2Ch), 31,200 bit/s (2Dh), 33,600 bit/s (2Eh), 32,000 bit/s (2Fh), 56,000 bit/s (30h), and 64,000 bit/s (31h).

instruction: What are the recommended test parameters for comparative tests of modems over telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: 1 List of test parameters (see Table 1/V.56) TABLE 1/V.56 Test parameters Ref. No. Parameter Four-wireTwo-wire switched network point-to-point Serial modemsParallel modems 123456789 10111213Total attenuation or receiving signal level Attenuation distortionEnvelope or group delay distorsionFrequency shift (or offset)Sudden changes of attenuationInterruptionsPhase hitsPhase jitterHarmonic distortionListener echo"White" noiseImplusive noiseSingle tone interferenceX XXXXXXXXX XX XXXXXXXXXXXXX
Standard: V.56
output: The recommended test parameters for comparative tests of modems over telephone-type circuits include total attenuation or receiving signal level, attenuation distortion, envelope or group delay distortion, frequency shift (or offset), sudden changes of attenuation, interruptions, phase hits, phase jitter, harmonic distortion, listener echo, 'white' noise, impulsive noise, and single tone interference. These parameters are applicable to both four-wire and two-wire switched networks, as well as point-to-point connections, and can be used for testing both serial and parallel modems.

instruction: What are the typical attenuation distortion values for Mode 1 at 300 Hz, 500 Hz, and 3000 Hz?
input:
Source: Frequency (Hz) Attenuation distortion (dB) Mode 1 (see Note 1) Mode 2 (see Note 2) Mode 3 (see Note 5) 300 500 800 ≈ 1600 2500 2800 3000 6 3 10 Unspecified 36 12 8 2 a) 0 8 Unspecified 12K 1 b) 0.35 K1 0 0 0.2 K1 0.3 K1 0.4 K1
Standard: V.56
output: For Mode 1, the typical attenuation distortion values are approximately 3 dB at 300 Hz, 10 dB at 500 Hz, and 6 dB at 3000 Hz. These values are subject to tolerances of ±5%.

instruction: What are the group-delay distortion values for Mode 1 at frequencies of 500 Hz, 600 Hz, and 1000 Hz?
input:
Source: FrequencyGroup-delay distortion (ms) (Hz)Mode 1 500 600 1000140018002200260028002.0 1.3 0 (see Note 3) 0.5 (see Note 4) 0 (see Note 3) 0.5 (see Note 4)0.3 (see Note 3) 2.0
Standard: V.56
output: For Mode 1, the group-delay distortion values are 2.0 ms at 500 Hz, 1.3 ms at 600 Hz, and 0 ms at 1000 Hz (with Note 3 indicating these are ripple valley values).

instruction: What is the recommended duration of the stop element in start-stop systems using the seven-unit code on switched telephone networks with electromechanical data terminal equipments operating at modulation rates up to and including 200 bauds?
input:
Source: that for start-stop systems using the seven-unit code on switched telephone networks, a two-unit stop element should be used with electromechanical data terminal equipments operating at modulation rates up to and including 200 bauds.
Standard: V.4
output: For start-stop systems using the seven-unit code on switched telephone networks with electromechanical data terminal equipments operating at modulation rates up to and including 200 bauds, a two-unit stop element should be used.

instruction: How may the detection of a character out-of-parity be represented?
input:
Source: that the detection of a character out-of-parity may be represented by: a) reverse question mark graphic character or a representation of the capital letters SB (see ISO 2047) provided that these letters occupy a single character position on the screen or printer, and could have been entered by a single key stroke, recognizing it may be difficult to achieve a legible 'SB' character from some matrix printers or displays where the characters are printed; or b) a recording of the 1/10 (SUB) character on the tape or other storage medium, where provided and that, where a SUB character occurs in a received transmission, or is presented to a DTE via a storage medium, e.g. paper tape, then the reaction should be as in a) and b) above.
Standard: V.4
output: The detection of a character out-of-parity may be represented by either a reverse question mark graphic character or a representation of the capital letters SB, provided these occupy a single character position and could be entered by a single key stroke. Alternatively, it may be represented by a recording of the 1/10 (SUB) character on the tape or other storage medium, where provided. In cases where a SUB character occurs in a received transmission or is presented to a DTE via a storage medium, the reaction should mirror the representations mentioned.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of modems designed for 2400 bit/s duplex data transmission over the General Switched Telephone Network and point-to-point 2-wire leased telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of these modems are as follows: a) duplex mode of operation on the GSTN and point-to-point leased circuits,b) channel separation by frequency division,c) quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 600 baud (nominal),d) inclusion of a scrambler,e) inclusion of an adaptive equalizer and a compromise equalizer,f)inclusion of test facilities, g) data signalling rates of: 2400 bit/s synchronous,2400 bit/s start-stop,1200 bit/s synchronous,1200 bit/s start-stop, h) it is compatible with a V.22 modem operating in Modes i) or ii) at the 1200 bit/s signalling rate and includes automatic bit rate recognition.
Standard: V.22
output: The principal characteristics include: a) duplex mode of operation on both the General Switched Telephone Network and point-to-point leased circuits, b) channel separation by frequency division, c) quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 600 baud (nominal), d) inclusion of a scrambler, e) inclusion of an adaptive equalizer and a compromise equalizer, f) inclusion of test facilities, g) support for data signalling rates of 2400 bit/s synchronous, 2400 bit/s start-stop, 1200 bit/s synchronous, and 1200 bit/s start-stop, h) compatibility with a V.22 modem operating at 1200 bit/s signalling rate with automatic bit rate recognition.

instruction: What are the carrier frequencies for the low and high channels in a modem?
input:
Source: The carrier frequencies shall be 1200 ± 0.5 Hz for the low channel and 2400 ± 1 Hz for the high channel.
Standard: V.22
output: The carrier frequency for the low channel is 1200 ± 0.5 Hz, and for the high channel, it is 2400 ± 1 Hz.

instruction: What are the threshold levels for circuit 109 to transition between ON and OFF states?
input:
Source: High channel threshold: - greater than -43 dBmcircuit 109 ON- less than -48 dBmcircuit 109 OFFLow channel threshold:- greater than -43 dBmcircuit 109 ON- less than -48 dBmcircuit 109 OFFThe condition of circuit 109 between the ON and OFF levels is not specified except that the signal detector shall exhibit a hysteresis action, such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs shall be at least 2 dB greater thanthat for the ON to OFF transition.
Standard: V.22
output: The high and low channel thresholds for circuit 109 are greater than -43 dBm for the ON state and less than -48 dBm for the OFF state. The signal detector must exhibit hysteresis, with the OFF to ON transition level at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition level.

instruction: What are the key electrical characteristics to consider for generator and load in signal transmission systems?
input:
Source: 4 Electrical characteristics...4.1 Generator characteristics...4.2 Load characteristics
Standard: V.12
output: For generators, key characteristics include open circuit voltage, output signal waveform under load, and performance during short-circuit conditions. Open circuit measurements assess voltage without load, while test termination measurements evaluate performance with specific loads. Short-circuit measurements check the generator's ability to handle fault conditions. The output signal waveform must remain stable and within specified parameters under varying loads. For loads, important characteristics include input current-voltage relationships, sensitivity to input signals, proper cable termination to prevent reflections, and fail-safe operation to ensure system stability during faults. Input sensitivity measurements determine the minimum signal level required for reliable operation, while fail-safe operation ensures the system defaults to a safe state during failures.

instruction: What is the maximum data signaling rate for a balanced digital interchange circuit?
input:
Source: The balanced digital interchange circuit will normally be utilized on data and timing, or control circuits where the data signalling rate is up to a maximum limit of 52 Mbit/s.
Standard: V.12
output: The maximum data signaling rate for a balanced digital interchange circuit is 52 Mbit/s.

instruction: What is the maximum data signalling rate for a balanced digital interchange circuit?
input:
Source: The balanced digital interchange circuit will normally be utilized on data and timing, or control circuits where the data signalling rate is up to a maximum limit of 52 Mbit/s.
Standard: V.12
output: The maximum data signalling rate for a balanced digital interchange circuit is 52 Mbit/s.

instruction: What are the two modes of operation specified for the T.38-to-interworking function?
input:
Source: Two modes of operation are specified for the T.38-to-V.152 interworking function: native versus emulated interworking.
Standard: V.153
output: The two modes of operation specified for the T.38-to-V.152 interworking function are native and emulated interworking.

instruction: What are the principal modes of operation defined for VBDoIP and FoIP interworking?
output: The principal modes of operation defined for VBDoIP and FoIP interworking are Emulation mode and Native mode. Emulation mode involves the simulation of traditional telephony signals over IP networks, while Native mode directly utilizes IP-based protocols for communication. Methods for discrimination between these modes are also specified to ensure proper interworking functionality.

instruction: What are the three major application areas of voiceband data in the context of VoIP gateways?
input:
Source: Teleservices may be categorized into three major applications areas: facsimile, text-based communication and general data services. The three VBD application areas may be summarized as (by using notation 'application/transport'): – Facsimile/modem : Gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, see, e.g., [ITU-T V.152] for pass-through mode and [ITU-T T.38] for packet relay mode. – Text/modem : Gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, see, e.g., [ITU-T V.152] for pass-through mode and [b-ITU-T V.151] for packet relay mode. – Data/modem : Gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, see, e.g., [ITU-T V.152] for pass-through mode and [b-ITU-T V.150.1] for packet relay mode.
Standard: V.153
output: The three major application areas of voiceband data in the context of VoIP gateways are facsimile/modem, text/modem, and data/modem. Facsimile/modem involves gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, such as pass-through mode described in ITU-T V.152 and packet relay mode in ITU-T T.38. Text/modem also involves PSTN-to-IP interworking technologies, with pass-through mode in ITU-T V.152 and packet relay mode in ITU-T V.151. Data/modem similarly uses pass-through mode in ITU-T V.152 and packet relay mode in ITU-T V.150.1 for PSTN-to-IP interworking.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Modem-on-hold request acknowledged feature in modems?
input:
Source: Figure 20/V.92 − Modem-on-hold request acknowledged
Standard: V.92
output: The Modem-on-hold request acknowledged feature in V.92 modems allows the modem to temporarily suspend the data connection while maintaining the line connection, enabling the user to receive an incoming voice call without disconnecting the data session. This feature is particularly useful for users who need to switch between data and voice services on the same telephone line.

instruction: What is the required duration of silence a digital modem should transmit after detecting Tone A for more than 50 ms before proceeding with Tone B?
input:
Source: After detecting Tone A for more than 50 ms, the digital modem shall turn OFF circuit 106, clamp circuit 104 to binary one and transmit silence for 70 ± 5 ms. The digital modem shall then transmit Tone B, condition its receiver to detect a Tone A phase reversal, and proceed in accordance with the full Phase 2 start-up procedure.
Standard: V.92
output: The digital modem should transmit silence for 70 ± 5 ms after detecting Tone A for more than 50 ms before proceeding to transmit Tone B.

instruction: What is the purpose of the synchronizing signal in data transmission?
input:
Source: For the whole duration of the interval between the OFF to ON transitions of circuits 105 and 106, the line signal shall be that corresponding to the continuous transmission of dibit 11. This shall be known as the synchronizing signal.
Standard: V.26
output: The synchronizing signal ensures the stability of timing recovery at the receiver by providing a continuous transmission of dibit 11 during the interval between the OFF to ON transitions of circuits 105 and 106. This helps mitigate data-pattern sensitivity issues in timing recovery.

instruction: What are the threshold levels and response times for circuit 109 to turn OFF and ON?
input:
Source: A fall in level of the incoming line signal to -31 dBm or lower for more than 10 ± 5 ms will cause circuit 109 to be turned OFF. An increase in level to -26 dBm or higher will, within 10 ± 5 ms, turn this circuit ON. The condition of circuit 109 for levels between -26 dBm and -31 dBm is not specified except that the signal level detector shall exhibit a hysteresis action such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs is at least 2 dB greater than that for the ON to OFF transition.
Standard: V.26
output: Circuit 109 turns OFF when the incoming line signal level falls to -31 dBm or lower for more than 10 ± 5 ms. It turns ON when the signal level increases to -26 dBm or higher within 10 ± 5 ms. The condition of circuit 109 for levels between -26 dBm and -31 dBm is not specified, except that the signal level detector must exhibit hysteresis, ensuring the OFF to ON transition occurs at a level at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition.

instruction: What are the response time specifications for circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON under infrequent operation conditions?
input:
Source: OFF to ON 65-100 ms (see Note 1)
Standard: V.26
output: The response time for circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON under infrequent operation conditions is 65-100 ms.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of a 9600 bits per second modem for leased circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of this recommended modem for transmitting data at 9600 bits per second on leased circuits are as follows: a) fallback rates of 7200 and 4800 bits per second;b) capable of operating in a duplex or half-duplex mode with continuous or controlled carrier;c) combined amplitude and phase modulation with synchronous mode of operation;d) inclusion of an automatic adaptive equalizer;e) optional inclusion of a multiplexer for combining data rates of 7200, 4800 and 2400 bits per second (see Note 3).
Standard: V.29
output: The principal characteristics include: fallback rates of 7200 and 4800 bits per second; capability to operate in duplex or half-duplex mode with continuous or controlled carrier; use of combined amplitude and phase modulation with synchronous operation; inclusion of an automatic adaptive equalizer; and optional inclusion of a multiplexer for combining data rates of 7200, 4800, and 2400 bits per second.

instruction: How are quadbits formed from the scrambled data stream at a transmission rate of 7200 bits per second?
input:
Source: 2.2.2 At the fallback rate of 7200 bits per second, the scrambled data stream to be transmitted is divided into groups of three consecutive data bits. The first data bit in time determines Q2 of the modulator quadbit. The second and third data bits determine Q3 and Q4 respectively of the modulator quadbit. Q1 of the modulator quadbit is a data ZERO for each signal element.
Standard: V.29
output: At 7200 bits per second, the scrambled data stream is divided into groups of three consecutive data bits. The first data bit determines Q2 of the modulator quadbit, the second data bit determines Q3, and the third data bit determines Q4. Q1 of the modulator quadbit is set to a data ZERO for each signal element.

instruction: What are the data signalling rates and modulation rate for the specified system?
input:
Source: The data signalling rates shall be 9600, 7200 and 4800 bits per second ± 0.01%. The modulation rate is 2400 bauds ± 0.01%.
Standard: V.29
output: The data signalling rates are 9600, 7200, and 4800 bits per second with a tolerance of ± 0.01%. The modulation rate is 2400 bauds with a tolerance of ± 0.01%.

instruction: What encoding rules should be used for ASN.1 in diagnostic information management for V-series modem DCEs?
input:
Source: The ASN.1 encoding in Annex A should employ the BASIC-ALIGNED version of Packed Encoding Rules (PER) according to ITU-T X.691.
Standard: V.59
output: The BASIC-ALIGNED version of Packed Encoding Rules (PER) should be employed for ASN.1 encoding in diagnostic information management for V-series modem DCEs.

instruction: What are the valid value ranges for txSpeed and rxSpeed in the DTEDCE sequence?
input:
Source: txSpeed     INTEGER (50..1677215),  rxSpeed     INTEGER (50..1677215),
Standard: V.59
output: The valid value ranges for both txSpeed and rxSpeed in the DTEDCE sequence are from 50 to 1677215.

instruction: What are the mnemonic codes and descriptions for call termination result codes in modem communications?
input:
Source: Table 17/V.59 −−−− Call Termination Result Codes (concluded)
Standard: V.59
output: The mnemonic codes and descriptions for call termination result codes include: noDialTone (47) for outgoing call failure due to no dial tone detected, voiceDetected (48) for connection failure due to voice detection, reorderTone (49) for call failure due to reorder tone detection, sitTone (50) for call failure due to special information tone detection, engagedTone (51) for call progress failure due to engaged tone detection, longSpaceDisconnect (52) for modem disconnection using long space criteria, carrierLost (60) for modem disconnection due to loss of carrier, trainingFailed (61) for modem disconnection due to training failure, noModulationinCommon (62) for connection failure due to no common modulation mode, retrainFailed (63) for connection failure due to retrain failures, retrainAttemptCountExceeded (64) for connection termination due to exceeded retrain count, gstnCleardownReceived (65) for connection termination with correct CLEARDOWN exchange, faxDetected (66) for connection termination due to facsimile terminal detection, protocolError (80) for connection termination due to excess protocol errors, userDisconnect (90) for connection termination due to user request, onHoldTimerExpired (100) for connection termination due to on-hold timer expiration, and onHoldRemoteDisc (101) for connection termination due to remote modem disconnection while on hold.

instruction: What is the purpose of the signals defined in the procedures for starting sessions of data transmission over the PSTN?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines signals to be exchanged between DCEs over the PSTN when a session of data transmission needs to be established, but before signals are exchanged which are specific to a particular Recommendation. It provides means to automatically determine the best available operational mode between two DCEs connected via the PSTN, provides a timely indication to Circuit Multiplication Equipments on the V-series modulation to be employed in a new session of data transmission, provides a means to enable a PSTN call to be passed on automatically to an appropriate DCE, and provides signals for interacting with PSTN echo-control equipment.
Standard: V.8
output: The signals defined in the procedures for starting sessions of data transmission over the PSTN serve multiple purposes. They enable the automatic determination of the best available operational mode between two DCEs connected via the PSTN. They provide a timely indication to Circuit Multiplication Equipments about the V-series modulation to be used in a new session of data transmission. Additionally, they facilitate the automatic passing of a PSTN call to an appropriate DCE and offer signals for interacting with PSTN echo-control equipment.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Call Menu signal CM in data communication?
input:
Source: 7.3 The Call Menu signal CM
Standard: V.8
output: The Call Menu signal CM is used in data communication to facilitate the exchange of call setup information between devices. It contains details about the call functions and capabilities that the calling device supports, enabling the answering device to understand and respond appropriately to establish a compatible communication session.

instruction: What are the key characteristics of a 2400 bits per second duplex modem using frequency division technique?
input:
Source: ITU-T V.22 bis (1988), 2400 bits per second duplex modem using the frequency division technique standardized for use on the general switched telephone network and on point-to-point 2-wire leased telephone-type circuits.
Standard: V.8
output: A 2400 bits per second duplex modem using frequency division technique is designed for use on the general switched telephone network and on point-to-point 2-wire leased telephone-type circuits. It operates by dividing the available frequency band into separate channels for simultaneous transmission and reception, enabling full-duplex communication.

instruction: What is the purpose of ITU-T Study Groups?
input:
Source: The ITU-T (Telecommunication Standardization Sector) is a permanent organ of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). The ITU-T is responsible for studying technical, operating and tariff questions and issuing Recommen-dations on them with a view to standardizing telecommunications on a worldwide basis.
Standard: V.38
output: ITU-T Study Groups are responsible for studying technical, operating, and tariff questions in the field of telecommunications. They produce Recommendations with the aim of standardizing telecommunications on a worldwide basis.

instruction: What are the typical data signalling rates mentioned for interfaces?
output: The typical data signalling rates for V.38 interfaces include rates below 48 kbit/s, with specific mention of a 64 kbit/s rate for scrambler and descrambler functions.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of a DCE intended for use on 56-kbit/s and 64-kbit/s digital point-to-point leased circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of the DCE are as follows: a) duplex mode of operation on digital leased circuits (see Note 1);b) gross bit rates of at least 56 kbit/s;c) signalling rates up to 56/64 kbit/s;d) rate adaptation of 48 kbit/s and 56 kbit/s into 64 kbit/s according to schemes specified in Recommendation V.110; e) inclusion of two different types of DTE-DCE functional interfaces;f) inclusion of testing facilities;g) optional provision of a means to differentiate between user and network data; h) optional inclusion of a multiplexer (for further study);i) optional inclusion of an equipment management function.
Standard: V.38
output: The principal characteristics include: duplex mode of operation on digital leased circuits; gross bit rates of at least 56 kbit/s; signalling rates up to 56/64 kbit/s; rate adaptation of 48 kbit/s and 56 kbit/s into 64 kbit/s; inclusion of two different types of DTE-DCE functional interfaces; inclusion of testing facilities; optional provision of a means to differentiate between user and network data; optional inclusion of a multiplexer; and optional inclusion of an equipment management function.

instruction: What is the purpose of data flow control in DTEs and DCEs?
input:
Source: This Recommendation | International Technical Report provides guidance for the choice of an appropriate method for, and the implementation of, data flow control capabilities in DTEs and DCEs. It also coordinates information from other Recommendations and International Standards and provides tutorial material on these flow control techniques.
Standard: V.43
output: Data flow control in DTEs (Data Terminal Equipment) and DCEs (Data Circuit-terminating Equipment) is designed to manage the rate of data transmission between devices to prevent data overflow or loss. It ensures that the receiving device can process the incoming data at a rate that matches the sender's transmission speed, thereby optimizing communication efficiency and reliability.

instruction: What are the two primary modes of operation for data flow control in transmission systems?
output: The two primary modes of operation for data flow control in transmission systems are the asynchronous mode and the synchronous mode. In the asynchronous mode, data is transmitted without a shared clock signal, with start and stop bits framing each character. In the synchronous mode, data is transmitted in a continuous stream, synchronized by a shared clock signal, allowing for higher data rates and efficiency.

instruction: Why is flow control essential in DCEs incorporating data compression and/or error correction?
input:
Source: When using DCEs incorporating data compression and/or error correction, it is essential that the DCE have some method of controlling the flow of data from the DTE (a similar requirement applies for the associated DTEs; see below). This is because the degree of compression obtained will vary from moment to moment, and the buffers in the DCE may fill up during periods of lower compression, or while correction of transmission errors is active. Likewise, during periods of high compression, the DTE may become overloaded with the amount of incoming data and may not be able to process this data properly without means of controlling the flow of data from the DCE.
Standard: V.43
output: Flow control is essential in DCEs with data compression and/or error correction because the degree of compression varies over time. During periods of lower compression or active error correction, buffers in the DCE may fill up. Conversely, during high compression, the DTE may become overloaded with incoming data, risking improper processing. Flow control mechanisms prevent these issues by regulating data flow between DTE and DCE.

instruction: What are the four types of loops defined for modem loop testing procedures?
input:
Source: Four loops are defined (numbered 1 to 4) and their locations as seen from DTE A are shown in Figure 1/V.54. A symmetrical set of four loops could exist as seen from DTE B.
Standard: V.54
output: The four types of loops defined for modem loop testing procedures are numbered 1 to 4. These loops are located as seen from DTE A, with a symmetrical set of four loops potentially existing as seen from DTE B. The specific characteristics and locations of these loops are designed to facilitate local or remote measurements, both analogue and digital, for fault locating in modems.

instruction: What is the purpose of Loop 1 in DTE testing?
input:
Source: This loop is used as a basic test on the operation of the DTE, by returning transmitted signals to the DTE for checking. The loop should be set up inside the DTE as close as possible to the interface. While the DTE is in the loop 1 test condition: - transmitted data (circuit 103) are connected to received data (circuit 104) within the DTE;- circuit 108/1 or 108/2 must be in the same condition as it was before the test;- circuit 105 must be in the OFF condition;- circuit 125 should continue to be monitored by the DTE so that an incoming call can be given priority over a routine loop test.
Standard: V.54
output: Loop 1 is used as a basic test to verify the operation of the DTE by returning transmitted signals back to the DTE for checking. It is set up inside the DTE as close as possible to the interface. During this test, transmitted data (circuit 103) are connected to received data (circuit 104) within the DTE, circuit 108/1 or 108/2 must remain in its pre-test condition, circuit 105 must be OFF, and circuit 125 should continue to be monitored to prioritize incoming calls over routine loop tests.

instruction: What are the conditions of circuits 104, 109, 106, and 107 to the DTE when DCE B is in the loop 2 test condition?
input:
Source: - circuit 104 to the DTE is maintained in the binary 1 condition;- circuit 109 to the DTE is maintained in the OFF condition;- circuit 106 to the DTE is maintained in the OFF condition;- circuit 107 to the DTE is maintained in the OFF condition;
Standard: V.54
output: When DCE B is in the loop 2 test condition, circuit 104 to the DTE is maintained in the binary 1 condition, circuit 109 to the DTE is maintained in the OFF condition, circuit 106 to the DTE is maintained in the OFF condition, and circuit 107 to the DTE is maintained in the OFF condition.

instruction: What are the procedures for simultaneous transmission of data and digitally encoded voice signals over GSTN or 2-wire leased point-to-point telephone type circuits?
input:
Source: Procedures for the simultaneous transmission of data and digitally encoded voice signals over the GSTN, or over 2-wire leased point-to-point telephone type circuits
Standard: V.70
output: The procedures involve the simultaneous transmission of data and digitally encoded voice signals over General Switched Telephone Networks (GSTN) or 2-wire leased point-to-point telephone type circuits. This includes corrections and clarifications on the completion of capability exchange, usage of H.245 'max BitRate', preferred use of AlternativeCapabilitySet structure, terminology for simultaneous capability sets, support of G.729 Annex B, and enabling negotiation of the Suspend/Resume Option as per V.8 bis.

instruction: What functions can an out-of-band control channel (DLC) perform in a DSVD terminal?
input:
Source: The SCF may optionally initiate th e establishment of an out-of-ba nd control channel (DLC) for various functions including terminal capability (mux, voice and data) exchange. The support of an out-of-band control channel by a DSVD terminal is optional. If an out-of-band capability exchange is performed, the capabilities so co nveyed can be used as a basis fo r selecting how to subsequently operate a DLC. This capability exchange is add itional to any capability exchange which may have taken place using V.8  bis procedures, and includes more detailed information.
Standard: V.70
output: An out-of-band control channel (DLC) in a DSVD terminal can perform various functions including terminal capability exchange for multiplexing, voice, and data. It can also be used for negotiating the optional suspend/resume mode of operation. The support of an out-of-band control channel is optional for a DSVD terminal.

instruction: What is the purpose of the AlternativeCapabilitySet structure in terminal capability exchange?
input:
Source: The transmitting terminal assigns a number in a capabilityTable to each individual mode in which the terminal is capable of operating. For example, G.729 Annex A speech, G.728 speech and T.434 binary file transfer would each be assigned separate numbers. These capability numbers are grouped into AlternativeCapabilitySet structures. Each AlternativeCapabilitySet indicates that the terminal is capable of operating in exactly one mode listed in the set.
Standard: V.70
output: The AlternativeCapabilitySet structure is used to indicate that a terminal can operate in exactly one mode listed within the set. It groups individual capability numbers, each representing a specific operational mode the terminal supports, such as different speech codecs or binary file transfer protocols. This structure allows the terminal to specify that it can operate in any one of the listed modes but not more than one simultaneously.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics for single-current interchange circuits using optocouplers operating at data signalling rates up to 1200 bit/s?
input:
Source: In general, the electrical characteristics specified in this Recommendation apply to interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates up to 75 bit/s, which have been covered in Recommendation V.31, and also to interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates up to 1200 bit/s. The electrical characteristics are specified to provide compatibility with existing equipment according to Recommendation V.31 which meet the voltage and current values given in Table 1/V.31 bis. The resistance values defined in Recommendation V.31 are converted into current and voltage values to meet the optocouplers requirements. If the signal receive side is in the data circuit-terminating equipment, the insulation resistance in the ON or OFF condition measured from either leg to ground or to any other interchange circuit shall not fall below 5 megohms and the capacitance measured between the same points shall not exceed 1000 picofarads. The current I0, which represents the reverse current of the optocouplers in the OFF condition, should not exceed 10 µA. The capacitance of the signal source Cg including that of the interface cable, measured at the interface, should not exceed 2500 pF.
Standard: V.31
output: The electrical characteristics for single-current interchange circuits using optocouplers include operation at data signalling rates up to 1200 bit/s, with insulation resistance not falling below 5 megohms and capacitance not exceeding 1000 picofarads when measured from either leg to ground or to any other interchange circuit. The signal source must be isolated from ground, with a reverse current (I0) in the OFF condition not exceeding 10 µA and a signal source capacitance (Cg) including interface cable not exceeding 2500 pF.

instruction: What are the voltage and current specifications for the signal receive side in a DCE?
input:
Source: The open circuit voltage Vr on the signal receive side of the DCE, measured at the interface (see Figure 1/V.31 bis), should not fall below 3 V and should not exceed 25 V. The polarity of Vr has to be chosen for the current direction DTE to DCE in the go lead and DCE to DTE in the return lead. The current I1 supplied by the receive side in the DCE should not fall below 0.1 mA and should not exceed 5 mA, when measured at the interface in the ON (or 1) condition. The voltage at the interface Vs, measured between the go and return leads in the ON (or 1) condition, should not exceed 1 V.
Standard: V.31
output: The open circuit voltage Vr on the signal receive side of the DCE should be between 3 V and 25 V, with polarity chosen for current direction DTE to DCE in the go lead and DCE to DTE in the return lead. The current I1 supplied by the receive side in the DCE should be between 0.1 mA and 5 mA in the ON (or 1) condition. The voltage at the interface Vs, measured between the go and return leads in the ON (or 1) condition, should not exceed 1 V.

instruction: What are the voltage and current limits for the signal receive side of a DTE at the interface?
input:
Source: The open circuit voltage Vr of the signal receive side of the DTE, measured at the interface (see Figure 1/V.31 bis), should not fall below 3 V and should not exceed 25 V. The polarity of Vr has to be chosen for the current direction DTE to DCE in the go lead and DCE to DTE in the return lead. The current I1, supplied by the signal receive side in the DTE, should not fall below 0.1 mA and should not exceed 15 mA, when measured at the interface (see Figure 1/V.31 bis), in the ON (or 1) condition.
Standard: V.31
output: The open circuit voltage Vr of the signal receive side of the DTE should not fall below 3 V and should not exceed 25 V. The current I1, supplied by the signal receive side in the DTE, should not fall below 0.1 mA and should not exceed 15 mA when measured at the interface in the ON (or 1) condition.

instruction: What are the maximum data signalling rates for downstream and upstream in a digital and analogue modem pair on the PSTN?
input:
Source: A digital modem and analogue modem pair for use on the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) at data signalling rates of up to 56 000 bit/s downstream and up to 33 600 bit/s upstream
Standard: V.90
output: The maximum data signalling rates are up to 56,000 bit/s downstream and up to 33,600 bit/s upstream for a digital and analogue modem pair on the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN).

instruction: What are the typical data signalling rates for a digital modem?
input:
Source: 5.1 Data signalling rates
Standard: V.90
output: Digital modems typically support data signalling rates up to 56 kbps downstream and 33.6 kbps upstream, depending on the line conditions and modem capabilities.

instruction: What are the key phases in the operation of a modem?
output: The key phases in the operation of a V.90 modem include Phase 1 – Network interaction, Phase 2 – Probing/ranging, Phase 3 – Equaliser and echo canceller training and digital impairment learning, Phase 4 – Final training, Retrains, Rate renegotiation, and Cleardown. Each phase involves specific procedures for both digital and analogue modems to establish, maintain, and terminate communication.

instruction: What is the purpose of the International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee (CCITT)?
input:
Source: The CCITT (the International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee) is the permanent organ of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). CCITT is responsible for studying technical, operating and tariff questions and issuing recommendations on them with a view to standardizing telecommunications on a worldwide basis.
Standard: V.42
output: The International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee (CCITT) is responsible for studying technical, operating, and tariff questions related to telecommunications. It issues recommendations with the aim of standardizing telecommunications on a global scale.

instruction: What is the definition of a character in data communication?
input:
Source: Single data element, encoded using a predefined number of bits (N3 = 8).
Standard: V.42
output: In data communication, a character is defined as a single data element that is encoded using a predefined number of bits, typically 8 bits (N3 = 8).

instruction: What is the purpose of a leaf node in a tree structure used for string representation?
input:
Source: Point on a tree which represents, within the context of this Recommendation, the last character in a string (see § 6.1).
Standard: V.42
output: A leaf node in a tree structure represents the last character in a string, marking the termination point of that particular string within the data structure.

instruction: What is the maximum rate at which an impulsive noise measuring instrument can record impulses exceeding the threshold?
input:
Source: The maximum rate at which the instrument can record impulses exceeding the threshold is 8  ±  2 counts per second.
Standard: Unknown
output: The maximum rate at which the instrument can record impulses exceeding the threshold is 8 ± 2 counts per second.

instruction: What are the attenuation characteristics for frequencies below 200 Hz in a flat bandwidth response?
input:
Source: below 200 Hz, the attenuation shall rise at about 18 dB per octave; at 100 Hz, minimum attenuation 17 dB;
Standard: Unknown
output: Below 200 Hz, the attenuation rises at approximately 18 dB per octave, with a minimum attenuation of 17 dB at 100 Hz.

instruction: What are the requirements for rectangular pulses to correctly operate a counter in terms of duration and amplitude?
input:
Source: rectangular pulses of either polarity of 50 milliseconds duration having a peak amplitude of 1.21 V with an intervalbetween pulses in excess of the dead time shall be applied to the instrument and cause the counter to operate at thecorrect rate. When the width of these pulses is gradually reduced, the counter shall count at the correct rate when thepulses have a duration of 50 microseconds but shall not count when the pulses are 20 microseconds.
Standard: Unknown
output: Rectangular pulses of either polarity with a duration of 50 milliseconds and a peak amplitude of 1.21 V, with an interval between pulses exceeding the dead time, are required to correctly operate the counter. The counter should operate at the correct rate when the pulse duration is gradually reduced to 50 microseconds but should not count when the pulses are 20 microseconds.

instruction: What is the maximum data signalling rate supported by a duplex modem operating on the general switched telephone network and leased point-to-point 2-wire telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: A DUPLEX MODEM OPERATING AT DATA SIGNALLING RATES OF UP TO 14 400 bit/s FOR USE ON THE GENERAL SWITCHED TELEPHONE NETWORK AND ON LEASED POINT-TO-POINT 2-WIRE TELEPHONE-TYPE CIRCUITS
Standard: V.32
output: The maximum data signalling rate supported by a duplex modem operating on the general switched telephone network and leased point-to-point 2-wire telephone-type circuits is 14,400 bit/s.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of a duplex modem operating at data signalling rates of up to 14,400 bit/s for use on general switched telephone networks and leased point-to-point 2-wire telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: A  DUPLEX  MODEM  OPERATING  AT  DATA  SIGNALLING  RATES  OF  UP  TO 14 400 bit/s  FOR  USE  ON  THE  GENERAL  SWITCHED  TELEPHONE NETWORK  AND  ON  LEASED  POINT-TO-POINT  2-WIRE TELEPHONE -TYPE  CIRCUITS... The principal characteristics of the modem are as follows: a) duplex mode of operation on GSTN and point-to-point 2-wire leased circuits;b) channel separation by echo cancellation techniques;c) quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 2400 symbols/s;d) the following synchronous data signalling rates shall be implemented in the modem: – 14 400 bit/s trellis coded,– 12 000 bit/s trellis coded,– 9600 bit/s trellis coded,– 7200 bit/s trellis coded, – 4800 bit/s uncoded; e) compatibility with Recommendation V.32 modems at 9600 and 4800 bit/s;f) exchange of rate sequences during start-up to establish the data signalling rate;g) a procedure to change the data signalling rate without retraining.
Standard: V.32
output: The principal characteristics include: a) duplex mode of operation on general switched telephone networks (GSTNs) and point-to-point 2-wire leased circuits; b) channel separation by echo cancellation techniques; c) quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 2400 symbols/s; d) implementation of synchronous data signalling rates: 14,400 bit/s trellis coded, 12,000 bit/s trellis coded, 9,600 bit/s trellis coded, 7,200 bit/s trellis coded, and 4,800 bit/s uncoded; e) compatibility with modems at 9,600 and 4,800 bit/s; f) exchange of rate sequences during start-up to establish the data signalling rate; g) a procedure to change the data signalling rate without retraining.

instruction: How is the data stream processed for transmission at 14,400 bits per second in a differential encoding system?
input:
Source: At 14 400 bits per second, the scrambled data stream to be transmitted is divided into groups of six consecutive data bits. The first two bits in time Q1 n and Q2 n in each group, where the subscript n designates the sequence number of the group, are first differentially encoded into Y1 n and Y2 n according to Table 1/V.32 bis. The two differentially encoded bits Y1 n and Y2 n are used as input to a systematic convolutional encoder which generates a redundant bit Y0 n (see Figure 1/V.32 bis). This redundant bit and the six information-carrying bits Y1 n, Y2n, Q3n, Q4n, Q5n, Q6n are then mapped into the coordinates of the signal element to be transmitted according to the signal space diagram shown in Figure 2-1/V.32 bis.
Standard: V.32
output: At 14,400 bits per second, the scrambled data stream is divided into groups of six consecutive data bits. The first two bits in each group, Q1n and Q2n, are differentially encoded into Y1n and Y2n using a specific coding table. These encoded bits are then input into a systematic convolutional encoder to generate a redundant bit Y0n. The redundant bit along with the six information-carrying bits (Y1n, Y2n, Q3n, Q4n, Q5n, Q6n) are mapped into the coordinates of the signal element to be transmitted, according to a predefined signal space diagram.

instruction: What are the layer 1 characteristics defined for a General Data Communications Interface?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines the layer 1 characteristics of a General Data Communications Interface (GDCI) between Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE) and/or Data Terminal Equipment (DTE). Applications include DTE-DCE interfaces, DCE-DCE interfaces, and possible DTE-DTE interfaces (see Figure 1/V.230). The interface specification isbased on the ISDN basic user-network interface defined in Recommendation I.430. The differences between the GDCI and theISDN basic user-network interface provide for the different wiring configurations expected for these interfaces, and theyprovide a means by which equipment conforming to V.230 can identify whether it has been connected to an interfaceoperating according to V.230 or to an interface operating according to I.430. The characteristics of the GDCI have beenchosen so that it is possible to design terminals which are compatible with both I.430 and V.230, and so that inadvertentconnection of I.430 equipment to a V.230 passive bus or of GDCI equipment to an I.430 passive bus will not result in passivebus malfunction.
Standard: V.230
output: The layer 1 characteristics defined for a General Data Communications Interface include the specification of a balanced metallic transmission medium for each direction of transmission, capable of supporting 192 kbit/s. It is designed for interfaces between Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE) and/or Data Terminal Equipment (DTE), including DTE-DCE, DCE-DCE, and possible DTE-DTE interfaces. The interface is based on the ISDN basic user-network interface but includes differences to accommodate different wiring configurations and to allow equipment to identify whether it is connected to a V.230 or I.430 interface.

instruction: What functions does Layer 1 provide in terms of transmission capability?
input:
Source: Layer 1 provides the transmission capability, by means of appropriately encoded bit streams, for the BV and DV channels and the related timing and synchronization functions. Note - The BV and DV channels correspond to the B and D channels, respectively, as defined in the I-Series Recommendations.
Standard: V.230
output: Layer 1 provides the transmission capability through appropriately encoded bit streams for the BV and DV channels, along with related timing and synchronization functions. The BV and DV channels correspond to the B and D channels as defined in the I-Series Recommendations.

instruction: What are the primitives associated with layer 1 in a communication system?
input:
Source: Primitives associated with layer 1
Specific name ParameterMessage unit contents
Generic name
Request Indication Priority
indicatorMessage unit
L1 < - - > L2
PH-DATA X

PH-DEACTIVATE X X - -

MPH-DEACTIVATE X X - -
MPH- INFORMATION - X - X Connected
Attached V-DCEAttached V-DTEAttached NTAttached TEDisconnected
Standard: V.230
output: The primitives associated with layer 1 include PH-DATA, PH-ACTIVATE, PH-DEACTIVATE, MPH-ERROR, MPH-ACTIVATE, MPH-DEACTIVATE, and MPH-INFORMATION. PH-DATA is used for layer 2 peer-to-peer messages, with its request implying negotiation between layer 1 and layer 2 for data acceptance. PH-ACTIVATE and PH-DEACTIVATE are used for activation and deactivation processes without priority indicators. MPH-ERROR reports errors or recovery from previously reported errors. MPH-ACTIVATE and MPH-DEACTIVATE are used for similar activation and deactivation processes at the management interface. MPH-INFORMATION provides status information such as connected, attached V-DCE, attached V-DTE, attached NT, attached TE, or disconnected states.

instruction: What are the key components of a data compression algorithm?
input:
Source: ITU-T Rec. V.44 (2000)/Cor.1 (03/2002) iii CONTENTS
Standard: V.44
output: A data compression algorithm typically includes several key components: an encoder that transforms the input data into a compressed format, a decoder that reconstructs the original data from the compressed format, and a set of rules or algorithms that define how the compression and decompression processes are performed. Additionally, it may involve techniques such as entropy coding, dictionary-based methods, or transform coding to reduce the size of the data efficiently.

instruction: What are the two methods for negotiating data compression parameters?
input:
Source: The negotiation of these parameter values may be done either through XID negotiation, or through Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment. XID negotiation is the default. Support of Parameter Mode negotiation is indicated in the V.44 capability parameter as shown in Table A.1. A modem supporting Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment shall also include V.44 compression parameters in its XID command frame (unless it intends to use default parameter values), since the responding modem may not support Parameter Mode negotiation.
Standard: V.44
output: The two methods for negotiating V.44 data compression parameters are through XID negotiation and through Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment. XID negotiation is the default method. Support for Parameter Mode negotiation is indicated in the V.44 capability parameter. A modem supporting Parameter Mode negotiation must also include V.44 compression parameters in its XID command frame unless default parameter values are intended, as the responding modem may not support Parameter Mode negotiation.

instruction: What conditions must be met before initiating Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment in modem communication?
input:
Source: If both modems indicate in their XIDs that Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment is supported, the control function may perform Parameter Mode negotiation at any time after link establishment, as it deems necessary. The parameter values from the XID negotiation, or default values (if compression parameters were not included in the XID), shall be used until the first Parameter Mode negotiation. The control function shall ensure that data transfer between the data compression peers is not in-progress, and that flow control is in-effect, prior to initiating parameter negotiation.
Standard: V.44
output: Before initiating Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment, the control function must ensure that data transfer between the data compression peers is not in-progress and that flow control is in-effect. Both modems must indicate in their XIDs that Parameter Mode negotiation after link establishment is supported.

instruction: What are the significant levels (V1) in the context of electrical signal characteristics?
input:
Source: 5 Significant levels ( V1)
Standard: V.28
output: Significant levels (V1) refer to the voltage thresholds that define the binary states in digital communication systems. Typically, these levels are used to distinguish between a logical '1' and a logical '0'. The exact values of V1 can vary depending on the specific communication standard or system design, but they are critical for ensuring reliable signal detection and interpretation.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits?
input:
Source: The electrical characteristics specified in this Recommendation apply generally to interchange circuits operating with data signalling rates below the limit of 20 kbit/s. However, for existing equipments, operation up to 64 kbit/s is possible under specific conditions which are described in Annex A. For new equipment intended for operation at data signalling rates above 20 kbit/s, consideration should be given to the use of electrical characteristics according to Recommendations V.10 and V.11. Figure 1 shows the interchange equivalent circuit with the electrical parameters, which are defined below. This equivalent circuit is independent of whether the generator is located in the data circuit-terminating equipment and the load in the data terminal equipment or vice versa.
Standard: V.28
output: The electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits include operation with data signalling rates below 20 kbit/s, with existing equipment capable of operation up to 64 kbit/s under specific conditions. The equivalent circuit involves parameters such as open-circuit generator voltage, total effective d.c. resistance and capacitance associated with both the generator and the load, measured at the interchange point. The circuit is independent of the generator's location, whether in the data circuit-terminating equipment or the data terminal equipment.

instruction: What are the requirements for the load impedance in an interchange circuit?
input:
Source: The impedance on the load side of an interchange circuit shall have a d.c. resistance ( RL) neither less than 3000 ohms nor more than 7000 ohms. With an applied voltage ( Em), 3 to 15 volts in magnitude, the measured input current ( I) shall be within the following limits: IEE RmL Lmin.,max.max. max.,min.=± The open-circuit load voltage ( EL) shall not exceed 2 volts. The effective shunt capacitance ( CL) of the load, measured at the interchange point, shall not exceed 2500 picofarads. To avoid inducing voltage surges on interchange circuits the reactive component of the load impedance shall not be inductive.
Standard: V.28
output: The load impedance in an interchange circuit must have a d.c. resistance (RL) between 3000 ohms and 7000 ohms. With an applied voltage (Em) of 3 to 15 volts, the input current (I) must be within specified limits. The open-circuit load voltage (EL) should not exceed 2 volts, and the effective shunt capacitance (CL) at the interchange point must not exceed 2500 picofarads. The reactive component of the load impedance should not be inductive to avoid inducing voltage surges on interchange circuits.

instruction: What are the power limitations for acoustically coupled data transmission equipment when used temporarily?
input:
Source: The maximum power output of the subscriber's equipment to the line shall not exceed 1 mW at any frequency. The mean permitted telephone line signal power shall not exceed -13 dBm0. 2) If p is the signal power in the frequency band 0-4 kHz, the signal power outside this band shall not exceed the following values when integrated over any period of approximately 3 seconds: p - 20 dB in the band 4 to 8 kHz, p - 40 dB in the band 8 to 12 kHz, p - 60 dB in each 4-kHz band above 12 kHz.
Standard: V.15
output: For temporary use of acoustically coupled data transmission equipment, the maximum power output to the telephone line must not exceed 1 mW at any frequency. The mean permitted telephone line signal power should not exceed -13 dBm0. Additionally, for signal power p in the 0-4 kHz band, the power outside this band must adhere to specific limits: p - 20 dB in the 4 to 8 kHz band, p - 40 dB in the 8 to 12 kHz band, and p - 60 dB in each 4-kHz band above 12 kHz, measured over any approximately 3-second period.

instruction: What are the requirements for frequencies emitted by a transducer to ensure compatibility with telephone systems?
input:
Source: The frequencies emitted by the transducer shall be such as not to interfere with national and international telephone signalling systems and pilot signals involved in the telephone connection envisaged.
Standard: V.15
output: The frequencies emitted by the transducer must not interfere with national and international telephone signalling systems and pilot signals involved in the telephone connection. This ensures compatibility and prevents disruption of telephone services.

instruction: What are the two types of transmission devices required for analogue transmission of medical data like ECGs over telephone networks?
input:
Source: This service requires two basically different transmission devices (modems): 1) transmission equipment for simultaneous transmission of three ECG signals on a telephone channel from a remote station to the central station, preferably for direct galvanic coupling to the telephone channel; 2) transmission equipment, preferably for emergency use and for monitoring of implanted pacemakers, to simultaneously transmit only one ECG signal from a remote station to a central station with acoustic or galvanic coupling to a telephone channel.
Standard: V.16
output: The two types of transmission devices required are: 1) Equipment for simultaneous transmission of three ECG signals on a telephone channel from a remote station to a central station, preferably for direct galvanic coupling to the telephone channel. 2) Equipment for simultaneous transmission of only one ECG signal from a remote station to a central station, preferably for emergency use and for monitoring implanted pacemakers, with acoustic or galvanic coupling to a telephone channel.

instruction: What are the baseband signal requirements for a modem input intended for simultaneous analogue transmission of three ECG records?
input:
Source: Baseband signal requirements at the modem input: - number of simultaneously transmitted ECG records 3 - frequency response of the separating amplifier flat - signal-to-noise ratio with 10 Hz square wave ≥ 50 dB signals ± 1 V (unweighted) - full scale limit (see Note 1) ± 2.5 V - linearity deviation of an ECG channel related to full scale and the optimum straight line 1% - permissible group delay distortion of the input from 3 to 60 Hz signal at the modulator input (including channel Δτ ≤ 2 ms (outside this range, filter in the baseband) see Figure 2/V.16)
Standard: V.16
output: The baseband signal requirements for a modem input include: transmission of 3 simultaneous ECG records, a flat frequency response of the separating amplifier, a signal-to-noise ratio of at least 50 dB with 10 Hz square wave signals of ±1 V (unweighted), a full scale limit of ±2.5 V, a linearity deviation of an ECG channel related to full scale and the optimum straight line of 1%, and permissible group delay distortion of the input signal at the modulator input (including channel filter in the baseband) from 3 to 60 Hz with Δτ ≤ 2 ms outside this range.

instruction: What is the time constant and corresponding lower cut-off frequency when a.c. coupling is applied in a system?
input:
Source: if a.c. coupling is applied, a time constant of τ = 3.2 s, corresponding to a lower cut-off frequency of 0.5 Hz, should be used.
Standard: V.16
output: When a.c. coupling is applied, a time constant of τ = 3.2 s is used, which corresponds to a lower cut-off frequency of 0.5 Hz.

instruction: What are the frequency characteristics used in parallel data transmission systems that utilize telephone signalling frequencies?
input:
Source: The transmission system uses two sets of frequencies in accordance with Recommendation Q.23 [1]. Each character is transmitted in the form of two simultaneously transmitted frequencies. These two frequencies belong to two separate sub-assemblies. Each of these two assemblies consists of four frequencies ['2 (1/4)' code]. This coding can thus be used to transmit 16 different character combinations and perhaps more (see Note). The actual transmission consists in sending a frequency pair for a time greater than 30 ms, followed by a silence period of not less than 25 ms.
Standard: V.19
output: The transmission system uses two sets of frequencies, with each character transmitted as two simultaneously transmitted frequencies. These frequencies belong to two separate sub-assemblies, each consisting of four frequencies, forming a '2 (1/4)' code. This coding allows for the transmission of 16 different character combinations. The actual transmission involves sending a frequency pair for a duration greater than 30 ms, followed by a silence period of not less than 25 ms.

instruction: What are the frequency pairs assigned to different digits in data transmission channels?
input:
Source: The 2 groups of 4 frequencies specified in Recommendation Q.23 [1] are defined as follows: - low group frequencies: 697, 770, 852, 941 Hz;- high group frequencies: 1209, 1336, 1477, 1633 Hz. The frequency pairs are assigned to the different digits as shown in Table 1/V.19.
Standard: V.19
output: The frequency pairs assigned to different digits are as follows: B1 = 1209 Hz, B2 = 1336 Hz, B3 = 1477 Hz, B4 = 1633 Hz for the high group frequencies, and A1 = 697 Hz, A2 = 770 Hz, A3 = 852 Hz, A4 = 941 Hz for the low group frequencies.

instruction: What is the recommended power level for an instation receiver to detect frequency pairs?
input:
Source: it is recommended that the instation receiver should be able to detect frequency pairs received at-45 dBm.
Standard: V.19
output: The instation receiver should be able to detect frequency pairs received at -45 dBm.

instruction: What is the purpose of a Data Coordinating Point in the context of public switched telephone networks?
input:
Source: Each country agreeing to the transmission of data over the public switched telephone network shall set up a Data Coordinating Point (DCP). This point: – shall be the contact point between Administrations for referring data transmission difficulties for investigation in respective national networks; – shall be the point to undertake discussions and agree on a course of action to be taken on public telephone network circuits regarding data transmission difficulties. It should be noted that agreement may be reached to take no actions regarding the international circuits; – shall initiate any actions related to national network extensions in accordance with its national practices and procedures.
Standard: Unknown
output: A Data Coordinating Point (DCP) serves as the contact point between Administrations for referring data transmission difficulties for investigation in respective national networks. It undertakes discussions and agrees on actions to be taken regarding data transmission difficulties on public telephone network circuits, including the possibility of taking no action on international circuits. Additionally, it initiates actions related to national network extensions in line with national practices and procedures.

instruction: What are the key functions covered in DCE initialization?
input:
Source: 4.1 DCE initialization
Standard: V.250
output: DCE initialization typically involves setting up the Data Circuit-terminating Equipment (DCE) for communication. Key functions include configuring communication parameters such as baud rate, parity, data bits, and stop bits, establishing the connection mode (e.g., synchronous or asynchronous), and initializing the modem or other communication devices for data transmission.

instruction: What are the common commands used by DTE to control DCE with asynchronous DTE-DCE connections?
input:
Source: ITU-T V.250 codifies the most common commands used by DTE to control DCE with asynchronous DTE-DCE connections. ITU-T V.250 also codifies the syntax to be used by standards committees for extending this command set in various ways.
Standard: V.250
output: The common commands used by DTE to control DCE with asynchronous DTE-DCE connections include basic command sets and extended syntax for various extensions. These commands facilitate control and data transmission between DTE and DCE devices, supporting protocols and services across different standards committees and industries.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +GCAP command in modem communication?
input:
Source: +GCAP 6.1.9/V.250 4.1.6/IS-1315.6/GSM07.07Request Complete Capabilities List
Standard: V.250
output: The +GCAP command is used to request the complete capabilities list of a modem, detailing all the supported features and services.

instruction: What is the purpose of the ITU-T Study Groups?
input:
Source: The ITU-T is responsible for studying technical, operating and tariff questions and issuing Recommen-dations on them with a view to standardizing telecommunications on a worldwide basis.
Standard: V.56
output: The ITU-T Study Groups are responsible for studying technical, operating, and tariff questions in the field of telecommunications. They produce Recommendations with the aim of standardizing telecommunications on a global scale.

instruction: What are the key components of a network model for modem testing?
input:
Source: 4 Description of model
4.1 Overview
4.2 Echo control requirements
4.3 Round-trip delay criteria
4.4 Modem impedance requirements
4.5 Model limitations
4.6 Digital impairment requirements
4.7 Network Model Coverage (NMC)
Standard: V.56
output: The key components of a network model for modem testing include echo control requirements, round-trip delay criteria, modem impedance requirements, digital impairment requirements, and Network Model Coverage (NMC). These components ensure the model accurately simulates real-world network conditions for comprehensive modem testing.

instruction: What is the purpose of the network model provided for 2-wire voiceband modems?
input:
Source: This Recommendation provides a network model to be used in the evaluation and comparison of 2-wire voiceband modems. The model is intended to be representative of the transmission impairment conditions that will be encountered on both intracontinental and intercontinental connections.
Standard: V.56
output: The network model is designed to evaluate and compare 2-wire voiceband modems by simulating transmission impairment conditions typically encountered on both intracontinental and intercontinental connections.

instruction: What are the key corrections and clarifications addressed in the corrigendum for the generic multiplexer using LAPM-based procedures?
input:
Source: This corrigendum addresses corrections and clarifications in ITU-T Rec. V.76 (1996) concerning CRC calculation when using suspend/resume, N401 timer value and reuse of DLCI values.
Standard: V.76
output: The corrigendum addresses corrections and clarifications in three main areas: CRC calculation when using suspend/resume, the N401 timer value, and the reuse of DLCI values.

instruction: What is the purpose of the N401 timer in data communication protocols?
input:
Source: Clarification of the N401 timer value
Standard: V.76
output: The N401 timer is used to manage the timing of frame transmissions in data communication protocols. It specifies the maximum time allowed for a response to a transmitted frame before the sender considers the transmission as failed and may attempt retransmission or other error recovery procedures. The exact value of the N401 timer can vary depending on the specific protocol implementation and network conditions.

instruction: What is the generator polynomial used for CRC calculation in LAPM-based procedures for 8-bit FCS?
input:
Source: the remainder of the division (modulo 2) by the generator polynomial x^8 + x^2 + x + 1, of the product of x^8 by the content of the frame existing between, but not including, the final bit of the opening flag and the first bit of the FCS, excluding bits inserted for transparency and real-time frames as defined in Annex A (including the bits of the suspend and resume flags).
Standard: V.76
output: The generator polynomial used for CRC calculation in V.42 LAPM-based procedures for 8-bit FCS is x^8 + x^2 + x + 1. This polynomial is applied to the content of the frame between, but not including, the final bit of the opening flag and the first bit of the FCS, excluding bits inserted for transparency and real-time frames, including the bits of the suspend and resume flags.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of a duplex modem operating at 1200 bits per second on 2-wire circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of this modem are as follows: a) duplex operation on 2-wire GSTN and point-to-point leased circuits, b) channel separation by frequency division,c) differential phase shift modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 600 bauds (nominal), d) inclusion of a scrambler,e) inclusion of test facilities.
Standard: V.22
output: The principal characteristics include duplex operation on 2-wire General Switched Telephone Networks (GSTNs) and point-to-point leased circuits, channel separation by frequency division, differential phase shift modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 600 bauds (nominal), inclusion of a scrambler, and inclusion of test facilities.

instruction: What are the carrier frequencies for the low and high channels in line signals?
input:
Source: The carrier frequencies shall be 1200 ± 0.5 Hz for the low channel and 2400 ± 1 Hz for the high channel.
Standard: V.22
output: The carrier frequency for the low channel is 1200 ± 0.5 Hz, and for the high channel, it is 2400 ± 1 Hz.

instruction: What are the data signalling rates and modulation rates for Alternatives A and B in modulation?
input:
Source: Alternatives A and B: The data signalling rate transmitted to line shall be 1200 bit/s or 600 bit/s ± 0.01% with a modulation rate of 600 baud ± 0.01%.
Standard: V.22
output: For Alternatives A and B in V.22 modulation, the data signalling rate transmitted to line is 1200 bit/s or 600 bit/s ± 0.01%, with a modulation rate of 600 baud ± 0.01%.

instruction: How are user rates coded in the Low layer compatibility subclause?
input:
Source: User rate (octet 5a) Bits 5 4 3 2 1 0 0 0 0 0 Unspecified Other rates are coded according to Recommendation Q.931.
Standard: V.120
output: User rates are coded in octet 5a, where bits 5 to 1 represent the rate. A code of '00000' indicates an unspecified rate, while other rates are coded according to the specific recommendations for data terminal equipment interfaces.

instruction: What is the purpose of the RTP payload format defined in Annex E of the text relay procedures?
input:
Source: Amendment 1 introduces Annex E, which defines the RTP payload format for the transport of text as T.140 character data over IP networks, removing the need to make a reference to an historic RFC published by the IETF.
Standard: V.151
output: The RTP payload format defined in Annex E is designed for the transport of text as T.140 character data over IP networks. This format facilitates the end-to-end connection of analogue PSTN text telephone terminals over an IP network by specifying how text data should be encapsulated and transmitted, eliminating the need to reference an outdated RFC from the IETF.

instruction: What are the main transport methods used in Text over IP (ToIP) systems?
output: The main transport methods used in Text over IP (ToIP) systems include audio mode, VBD (Voice Band Data) mode, and text relay mode. Audio mode is used for transmitting voice signals, VBD mode is utilized for data transmission over voice channels, and text relay mode is specifically designed for transmitting text data.

instruction: What are the key components of call discrimination procedures in telecommunication systems?
output: The key components of call discrimination procedures include V.8 bis processing, V.8 CI/XCI processing, call discrimination overview, call discrimination SDL diagrams, and visual flow control. These components work together to identify and manage different types of calls within the system.

instruction: What are the operational and interworking requirements for DCEs operating in the text telephone mode?
input:
Source: Operational and interworking requirements for DCEs operating in the text telephone mode Amendment 1 Summary The change is required because of an ambiguity in the original text which caused at least one manufacturer to make products incompatible with existing textphones. The new text removes the ambiguity and refers the reader to ANSI TIA/EIA-825 (2000) for the definition of operation of the existing type of textphone.
Standard: V.18
output: The operational and interworking requirements for DCEs operating in the text telephone mode include ensuring compatibility with existing textphones and removing any ambiguities in the operational definitions. These requirements are designed to facilitate seamless communication between different devices operating in this mode. The specifics of these requirements can be referenced in the ANSI TIA/EIA-825 (2000) standard for the definition of operation of the existing type of textphone.

instruction: What are the frequency specifications for binary 1 and binary 0 in 5-bit mode text telephone operation?
input:
Source: The modulation is frequency shift-keyed modulation (i.e. no carrier is present when a character is not being transmitted) using 1400 Hz ( ±5%) for a binary 1 and 1800 Hz ( ±5%) for a binary 0.
Standard: V.18
output: In 5-bit mode text telephone operation, binary 1 is represented by 1400 Hz (±5%) and binary 0 is represented by 1800 Hz (±5%).

instruction: What is the carrier frequency specified for line signals in modem communications?
input:
Source: 2.1 Carrier frequency
Standard: V.32
