Source: This Recommendation defines the basic framework and service Aspects of a Multi-Aspect Packet Assembly/Disassembly facility (MAP) in a Public Data Network. A MAP includes any Packet Assembly/Disassembly(PAD) Aspect defined by ITU-T, but is not limited to them. A MAP may also include non-ITU-T PAD Aspects, such asBinary Synchronous Communications PADs, SDLC PADs, T3POS PADs, generalized polling PAD (GPAD), et al. TheRecommendation does not specify particular network access methods nor protocol Aspects.
Standard: X.8
output: A Multi-Aspect Packet Assembly/Disassembly facility (MAP) in a Public Data Network is defined by its basic framework and service aspects. It includes any Packet Assembly/Disassembly (PAD) aspect defined by ITU-T, but is not limited to them. A MAP may also incorporate non-ITU-T PAD aspects such as Binary Synchronous Communications PADs, SDLC PADs, T3POS PADs, and generalized polling PAD (GPAD), among others. The MAP framework does not specify particular network access methods nor protocol aspects.

instruction: What method is used to transmit a single lower speed synchronous data channel on a 64 kbit/s data stream in networks using a 6 + 2 envelope structure?
input:
Source: The 6 + 2 envelopes related to the low speed channel shall be repeated as many times as required to reach the 64 kbit/s speed. The receive end can recover the original data signal by taking out of the received 64 kbit/s stream an envelope for every envelope period of the chosen data rate.
Standard: X.57
output: The method involves repeating the 6 + 2 envelopes related to the low speed channel as many times as required to reach the 64 kbit/s speed. The receive end recovers the original data signal by extracting an envelope for every envelope period of the chosen data rate from the received 64 kbit/s stream.

instruction: What are the key principles for routing international frame relay traffic?
input:
Source: The purpose of this Recommendation is to provide network operators with the information necessary to ensure that Frame Relay data traffic can be routed effectively and efficiently across the International Public Data Network. Guidelines and general principles for the planning of Public Frame Relay Data networks and the routing of International Frame Relay Traffic are provided. In particular guidance on the incorporation of service requirements into the network routing process is provided. Principles for routing in the case of Frame Relay/ATM interworking are also provided.
Standard: X.111
output: The key principles for routing international frame relay traffic include ensuring effective and efficient routing across the International Public Data Network, incorporating service requirements into the network routing process, and providing guidelines for routing in scenarios involving Frame Relay/ATM interworking. These principles aim to support network operators in planning Public Frame Relay Data networks and managing the routing of international traffic.

instruction: What are the key components involved in the routing process of frame relay traffic?
output: The key components involved in the routing process of frame relay traffic include the DTE-DCE interface, originating local switch, and transit networks and switches (both national and international). The DTE-DCE interface facilitates communication between data terminal equipment and data circuit-terminating equipment. The originating local switch initiates the routing process, while transit networks and switches handle the traffic as it moves through national and international networks.

instruction: What are the key components analyzed for routing in frame relay networks interworking with ATM?
output: The key components analyzed for routing in frame relay networks interworking with ATM include the calling party number, incoming route DLCI, called party number, bearer capability with link layer core parameters, priority and service class parameters, maximum end-to-end transit delay, transit network selection, network management conditions, and time, event, and state conditions.

instruction: What are the modem specifications for establishing an access information path for ship originated calls?
input:
Source: The access information path should be provided by the use of modems standardized for use in the public switched telephone network: i) At the rate of 300 bit/s for full duplex operation in accordance with Recommendation V.21. Channel No. 1 is to be used in the direction from the ship to the PAD and channel No. 2 in the opposite direction. Tone-disabling is required for disabling of echo suppressors. ii) At the rate of 1200 bit/s for full duplex operation in accordance with Recommendation V.22, alternative B, mode ii) with 10 bits per character (i.e. one start bit, eight information bits and one stop bit) [§ 4.2.1 b) ofRecommendation V.22]. The handshake procedure should be in accordance with Figure 4/V.22. The shipboard modem shall transmit in the low channel and receive in the high channel. The modem of the PADwill have the opposite channel configuration. Tone disabling is required for disabling of echo suppressors. iii) At the rate of 75/1200 bit/s in accordance with Recommendation V.23. The rate of 75 bit/s should be used for the direction from the on-board DTE to the PAD and the rate of 1200 bit/s should be used for the otherdirection. Tone disabling is required for disabling of echo suppressors. Note 1 - The alternative given in ii) above is preferred. Note 2 - Administrations may offer other additional data rates at the maritime PAD.
Standard: X.351
output: The modem specifications include three options: 1) 300 bit/s full duplex operation using two channels, with Channel No. 1 for ship to PAD direction and Channel No. 2 for the opposite direction, requiring tone-disabling for echo suppressors. 2) 1200 bit/s full duplex operation with 10 bits per character (one start bit, eight information bits, one stop bit), where the shipboard modem transmits in the low channel and receives in the high channel, and the PAD modem has the opposite configuration, also requiring tone-disabling. 3) 75/1200 bit/s operation, with 75 bit/s from the on-board DTE to the PAD and 1200 bit/s in the opposite direction, requiring tone-disabling. The 1200 bit/s option is preferred.

instruction: What are the dialling sequences for data signaling rates of 50 bit/s and 56,000 bit/s in the INMARSAT system?
output: For a data signaling rate of 50 bit/s, the dialling sequence is 2010. For a data signaling rate of 56,000 bit/s, the dialling sequence is 2017.

instruction: What is the role of the parity bit in 8-bit characters transmitted by a maritime PAD?
input:
Source: The PAD will transmit and expect to receive 8-bit characters, where the 8th bit (i.e. the last bit preceding the stop element) shall be the parity bit. The maritime PAD will detect the parity from the service request signal. The initial standard profile in Table 3/X.351 assumes that the even parity is used. However, the maritime PAD will also support the optional parameter values 1, 2 and 3 of parameter 21 (see Recommendation X.3).
Standard: X.351
output: In 8-bit characters transmitted by a maritime PAD, the 8th bit (the last bit preceding the stop element) serves as the parity bit. This bit is used for error detection purposes, ensuring the integrity of the data transmitted. The maritime PAD detects the parity from the service request signal, with the initial standard profile assuming the use of even parity. However, the maritime PAD also supports optional parameter values for parameter 21, allowing for different parity treatments if required by the on-board start-stop mode DTE.

instruction: What are the intended uses of the five hypothetical reference connections in synchronous data networks?
input:
Source: The five hypothetical reference connections set down in the present Recommendation (see Figure 1/X.92) are intended for assessing the overall customer-to-customer performance objectives, for determining some data characteristics requirements of the various items in the connections and for setting limits to the impairments these items may introduce. These hypothetical reference connections should be used for circuit-switched services, packet-switched services and leased line services in public synchronous data networks.
Standard: X.92
output: The five hypothetical reference connections are intended for assessing overall customer-to-customer performance objectives, determining data characteristics requirements of various items in the connections, and setting limits to the impairments these items may introduce. They are used for circuit-switched services, packet-switched services, and leased line services in public synchronous data networks.

instruction: What is the maximum number of satellite links allowed in a packet switching connection?
input:
Source: In any connection, the maximum number of links via satellite should not exceed three (see Note).Note - The maximum number of links via satellite allowable in a connection requires further study, in the light of signalling time-outs and quality of service considerations.
Standard: X.92
output: In a packet switching connection, the maximum number of links via satellite should not exceed three. This limitation is based on considerations of signalling time-outs and quality of service, although further study is required to fully determine the optimal maximum number.

instruction: What are the key considerations for ensuring continuous protection in the service access process?
input:
Source: Guidelines for continuous protection of the service access process
Standard: X.1011
output: Key considerations for ensuring continuous protection in the service access process include implementing robust authentication mechanisms, ensuring data integrity and confidentiality through encryption, monitoring for unauthorized access attempts, and maintaining up-to-date security protocols to address emerging threats. Additionally, it's crucial to have a comprehensive incident response plan to quickly address any security breaches.

instruction: What are the main challenges in preventing unauthorized access to ICT resources in cloud-based data centres?
input:
Source: The prevention of unauthorized access to information and abuse of information and communication technology (ICT) resources is fundamental to cyber security. An extensive effort had been made towards the standardization of identity and access management. However, the access environment is continuously changing and traditional mechanisms are unable to deal with the challenges of evolving security threats. This is firstly because traditional data centre infrastructure is moving to the cloud, and consequently the perimeter security devices for traditional data centres are not applicable to cloud-based data centres. Secondly, internal threats are becoming more and more serious, e.g., authorized users trying to perform dangerous operations caused by negligence, or internal users being attacked by social engineering which may lead to impersonation risks. Thirdly, the status of user devices or resources may become insecure during the access process, e.g., operating system (OS) or software in user devices and resource platforms being compromised by exploitation of misconfigurations, or access requests being intercepted, etc.
Standard: X.1011
output: The main challenges include the inapplicability of traditional perimeter security devices to cloud-based data centres, the increasing seriousness of internal threats such as negligence or social engineering attacks leading to impersonation risks, and the potential insecurity of user devices or resources during the access process due to misconfigurations or intercepted access requests.

instruction: What are the security threats associated with the service access process?
output: The security threats associated with the service access process include insufficiency of perimeter-based security mechanisms, risk of exposing services, risk of unknown devices, internal threats, privilege abuse, and leakage of sensitive information about access requests. These threats highlight vulnerabilities in protecting service access from unauthorized or malicious activities.

instruction: What are the general principles for interworking between public data networks and other networks for data transmission services?
input:
Source: that Recommendation X.300 defines the general principles for interworking between public data networks, and between public data networks and other networks for the provision of data transmission services;
Standard: X.324
output: The general principles for interworking between public data networks and other networks for data transmission services include defining the framework and methodologies to ensure seamless communication and data exchange. These principles encompass the establishment of call control arrangements, internal network utilities, and the support of OSI network service functionalities. They also involve specifying detailed procedures for call control between networks and categorizing access methods to public switched packet data networks (PSPDNs).

instruction: What are the general arrangements described for interworking between PSPDNs and mobile systems?
input:
Source: The purpose of this Recommendation is to describe the general arrangements for the interworking between PSPDNs and mobile systems for the provision of data transmission services. These arrangements are applicable only to the interworking involving transmission capabilities and not to interworking involving communication capabilities as described in Recommendation X.300.
Standard: X.324
output: The general arrangements for interworking between Packet Switched Public Data Networks (PSPDNs) and mobile systems focus on the provision of data transmission services. These arrangements are specifically applicable to interworking involving transmission capabilities, excluding communication capabilities. The setup includes all necessary capabilities to ensure seamless data transmission between these networks, based on the principles outlined for representing physical equipment collections as 'subnetworks' in interworking scenarios.

instruction: What are the two methods public mobile systems use to deal with user mobility?
input:
Source: Mobile systems deal with the mobility of their users in one of two ways:a) by requiring the calling user to specify one of a small number of zones as the location of the mobile user;b) by maintaining a data base containing the current location of each mobile station (called a location register in Recommendation Q.1001) and arranging for the interconnected fixed network(s) to route calls to anappropriate access point to the public mobile system. With such a mechanism, the calling user need not knowthe current location of the called mobile user. The first method (called designation method call routing to mobile users) is used in the public maritime mobile satellite system where the mobile station may be in one of three satellite regions. The second method (called non-designation method call routing to mobile users) is typified by systems conforming to the Q.1000 series of Recommendations.
Standard: X.324
output: Public mobile systems handle user mobility through two primary methods: a) The designation method, where the calling user specifies one of a small number of zones as the mobile user's location, commonly used in public maritime mobile satellite systems with three satellite regions. b) The non-designation method, which involves maintaining a database (location register) of each mobile station's current location, allowing the interconnected fixed network(s) to route calls to an appropriate access point without the calling user needing to know the called mobile user's current location, typical in systems conforming to the Q.1000 series of Recommendations.

instruction: What is the purpose of telebiometric access control with smart ID cards?
input:
Source: Telebiometric access control with smart ID cards
Standard: X.1093
output: Telebiometric access control with smart ID cards is designed to enhance security by combining biometric authentication with smart card technology. This system uses unique biological characteristics, such as fingerprints or facial recognition, stored on a smart ID card to verify an individual's identity, ensuring secure access to facilities or systems.

instruction: What are the three types of biometrics-on-card classification?
input:
Source: The biometrics -on-card can be classified into three types such as store-on-card, which is a form in which biometric information is stored in a smart card, compare-on-card in which biometric information is compared in a smart card, and sensor-on-card in which a biometric sensor is embedded in a smart card to acquire, store and compare the biometric information within the card.
Standard: X.1093
output: The three types of biometrics-on-card classification are store-on-card, where biometric information is stored in a smart card; compare-on-card, where biometric information is compared within a smart card; and sensor-on-card, where a biometric sensor is embedded in a smart card to acquire, store, and compare biometric information within the card.

instruction: What are the key components of a biometric-on-card based personal authentication system?
input:
Source: 6.2 Biometrics-on-card based personal authentication system
Standard: X.1093
output: A biometric-on-card based personal authentication system typically includes an access management system, biometric data stored on a card, and authentication processes. The system involves capturing biometric data, storing it securely on a card, and using it for identity verification during authentication processes. Key components include the biometric sensor for data capture, the card with secure storage for biometric templates, and the authentication mechanism that compares live biometric data with the stored template.

instruction: What are the key security considerations for big data as a service?
input:
Source: Guidelines on security of big data as a service for big data service providers
Standard: X.1750
output: Key security considerations for big data as a service include data confidentiality, integrity, and availability. It involves implementing robust encryption methods for data at rest and in transit, ensuring secure access controls and authentication mechanisms, and maintaining data integrity through checksums and hash functions. Additionally, service providers must ensure high availability and disaster recovery plans are in place to protect against data loss and service interruptions.

instruction: What are the key security challenges faced by Big Data as a Service (BDaaS)?
input:
Source: For example, open source big data software design sometimes fails to take security into consideration from the beginning. New technologies introduced by big data analytics can also result in failure of traditional security protection measures.
Standard: X.1750
output: The key security challenges faced by BDaaS include the initial design of open source big data software often lacking security considerations, and the introduction of new technologies through big data analytics that can render traditional security protection measures ineffective. These challenges necessitate a comprehensive approach to security, including the identification of security roles and responsibilities, and the implementation of a security framework tailored for big data infrastructure.

instruction: What are the security challenges to big data infrastructure?
input:
Source: 6.1 Security challenges to a big data infrastructure
Standard: X.1750
output: Security challenges to big data infrastructure include ensuring data integrity, confidentiality, and availability across distributed systems. Specific challenges involve protecting against unauthorized access, data breaches, and ensuring secure data transmission. Additionally, managing secure access controls and authentication mechanisms for large-scale distributed data storage and processing systems is critical.

instruction: What are the general principles and guidelines for routing international data traffic across interconnected public data networks?
input:
Source: This Recommendation provides high level general principles and guidelines that should be applied by Network Operators for the routing of international data traffic across interconnected public data networks. The aim of this Recommendation is to provide network operators with the necessary information to ensure that data traffic can be effectively and economically routed across interconnected public data networks making best use of the available network resources. Although this Recommendation is focused towards packet switched data networks (such as X.25 and Frame Relay), the principles are applicable to both circuit-switched and packet-switched public data networks.
Standard: X.110
output: The general principles and guidelines for routing international data traffic across interconnected public data networks include ensuring effective and economical routing to make the best use of available network resources. These principles are designed to be applicable to both circuit-switched and packet-switched public data networks, with a focus on packet-switched data networks such as X.25 and Frame Relay.

instruction: What are the general routing principles for international routes in PDNs?
output: The general routing principles for international routes in Public Data Networks (PDNs) involve ensuring efficient and reliable data transmission across international boundaries. These principles include maintaining quality of service, optimizing route selection based on network conditions, and ensuring compatibility between different types of networks involved in the route. Specific considerations may include the use of DNICs (Data Network Identification Codes) for network identification, number plan interworking to facilitate communication between different numbering schemes, and the application of escape codes for routing purposes in frame relay and ATM networks.

instruction: What are the different types of routes described in international routing plans?
output: International routing plans describe several types of routes including direct routes (high usage routes), routes via intermediate countries (for low volumes of traffic), and alternative routes. Additionally, they detail routing plans for scenarios where direct routes are either provisioned or not provisioned, and include considerations for rerouting.

instruction: What is the purpose of a cyber defence centre framework?
input:
Source: Framework for the creation and operation of a cyber defence centre
Standard: X.1060
output: The purpose of a cyber defence centre framework is to provide a structured approach for the creation and operation of a centre dedicated to cyber defence. It outlines the necessary components, processes, and management strategies to effectively monitor, detect, respond to, and mitigate cyber threats and incidents.

instruction: What are the main categories of services provided by a Cyber Defense Center (CDC)?
input:
Source: Annex A – CDC service list with descriptions
Standard: X.1060
output: The main categories of services provided by a Cyber Defense Center (CDC) include: Strategic management of CDC (Category A), Real-time analysis (Category B), Deep analysis (Category C), Incident response (Category D), Checking and evaluation (Category E), Collection, analysis and evaluation of threat intelligence (Category F), Development and maintenance of CDC platforms (Category G), Support of internal fraud response (Category H), and Active relationship with external parties (Category I).

instruction: What are the primary responsibilities of top management in managing cybersecurity risks within an organization?
input:
Source: Cybersecurity risks in an organization have significant impacts on its overall activities. The risks that organizations face are environmental changes, from both the social and business perspectives, and external pressures by regulations and increased threats. Top management, as the C-suite (CxO), is therefore responsible for managing controls for the entire organization to respond to these risks and changes. As one important aspect of implementing controls in cybersecurity, leadership in development and control security policies in alignment with business objectives is expected and is often provided by the chief security officer (CSO) or chief information security officer (CISO). In order practically to implement security measures, an entity that supports the activities of the CSO or CISO with strategic management at the organizational level is essentially required. This entity is described as a cyber defence centre (CDC) in this Recommendation.
Standard: X.1060
output: Top management, including the C-suite (CxO), is responsible for managing controls across the entire organization to address cybersecurity risks. This includes overseeing the development and enforcement of security policies that align with business objectives, often under the guidance of a chief security officer (CSO) or chief information security officer (CISO). Additionally, they must ensure the establishment of a supporting entity, such as a cyber defence centre (CDC), to strategically implement and manage security measures.

instruction: What are the key functionalities of ISDN in network interworking?
input:
Source: 6.2 Call control between ISDNs, 6.3 Functionalities of the ISDN, 7.1 Interworking between ISDNs, where a packet switched bearer is requested on each, 7.2 Interworking between ISDNs where a circuit switched bearer is requested on each, 7.3 Interworking between ISDNs where a frame relaying bearer is used on each
Standard: X.320
output: The key functionalities of ISDN in network interworking include call control between ISDNs, transfer of addressing information, arrangements for facilities related to the quality of service (QOS) of the call, charging conditions, specific routing conditions requested by the user, protection mechanisms, conveyance of user data in addition to the normal data flow in the data transfer phase, and other facilities for internal network utilities.

instruction: What are the methods for interworking between ISDNs when different bearer services are used?
output: The methods for interworking between ISDNs when different bearer services are used include call-control mapping and port access. Call-control mapping involves the translation of signaling and control information between the different bearer services to facilitate communication. Port access refers to the physical or logical connection points that allow the different bearer services to interface with each other, enabling data transfer between the disparate networks.

instruction: What is the purpose of interworking arrangements between ISDNs?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines general arrangements for the interworking between ISDNs for the provision of data transmission services. These arrangements are applicable only to the interworking involving transmission capabilitiesand not to interworking involving communication capabilities as described in Recommendation X.300.
Standard: X.320
output: The purpose of interworking arrangements between ISDNs is to facilitate the provision of data transmission services by defining general arrangements for their interworking. These arrangements are specifically applicable to interworking involving transmission capabilities, not communication capabilities.

instruction: What are the security requirements for integrating a quantum key distribution network with a secure storage network?
input:
Source: Security requirements and measures for integration of quantum key distribution network and secure storage network
Standard: X.1715
output: The security requirements for integrating a quantum key distribution network (QKDN) with a secure storage network include ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the quantum keys during transmission and storage. This involves implementing quantum-resistant encryption algorithms, secure key management protocols, and physical security measures to protect against eavesdropping and tampering. Additionally, the integration must support authentication mechanisms to verify the identity of communicating parties and ensure that only authorized entities can access the keys.

instruction: What are the key components involved in integrating a quantum key distribution network with a secure storage network?
input:
Source: Recommendation ITU-T X.1715 specifies security requirements and measures for integrating a quantum key distribution network (QKDN) with a secure storage network (SSN) in the service layer (Recommendation ITU-T Y.3800) and public key infrastructure (PKI) (Recommendation ITU-T X.509).
Standard: X.1715
output: The integration of a quantum key distribution network (QKDN) with a secure storage network (SSN) involves several key components, including the service layer and public key infrastructure (PKI). The service layer facilitates the interaction between QKDN and SSN, ensuring secure communication and data transfer. PKI provides a framework for managing digital keys and certificates, which are essential for authenticating entities and encrypting data in the integrated network.

instruction: What are the common security threats identified in SSN systems?
output: The common security threats identified in SSN systems include eavesdropping, spoofing, deletion or corruption of data, repudiation, and denial of service. Eavesdropping involves unauthorized interception of data. Spoofing refers to impersonating a legitimate entity to gain unauthorized access. Deletion or corruption involves intentionally altering or destroying data. Repudiation occurs when a party denies involvement in a transaction. Denial of service aims to disrupt services by overwhelming the system with requests.

instruction: What are the key quality of service metrics for characterizing Frame Relay/ATM service interworking performance?
input:
Source: Quality of service metrics for characterizing Frame Relay/ATM service interworking performance
Standard: X.142
output: The key quality of service metrics for characterizing Frame Relay/ATM service interworking performance include throughput, delay, delay variation (jitter), and packet loss ratio. These metrics are critical for ensuring the reliable and efficient transmission of data across interworked networks, where Frame Relay and ATM technologies are interconnected. Throughput measures the amount of data successfully transmitted over the network in a given time period. Delay refers to the time taken for a packet to travel from source to destination. Delay variation is the inconsistency in packet arrival times, which can affect real-time applications. Packet loss ratio indicates the percentage of packets lost during transmission, impacting the overall quality of service.

instruction: What are the quality of service metrics defined for characterizing Frame Relay/ATM service interworking performance?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines quality of service metrics for characterizing performance in the case of FR/ATM service interworking. The specified metrics can be used to quantify the performance of either the FR/ATM interworking function/unit or the quality of the end-to-end data connection. The metrics provide a simple manner by which either users or network operators could characterize the end-to-end performance. The defined metrics are not intended to be a replacement for the frame layer or ATM layer primary performance parameters but can be used to provide a user-oriented perspective of end-to-end performance.
Standard: X.142
output: The quality of service metrics defined for characterizing Frame Relay/ATM service interworking performance are designed to quantify the performance of either the FR/ATM interworking function/unit or the quality of the end-to-end data connection. These metrics provide a user-oriented perspective of end-to-end performance, allowing users and network operators to assess performance from a user perspective. They are not intended to replace frame layer or ATM layer primary performance parameters but complement them by offering a simple manner to characterize end-to-end performance.

instruction: What are the key metrics for characterizing FR/ATM service interworking performance?
output: The key metrics for characterizing FR/ATM service interworking performance include the data block delivered ratio/loss ratio, which measures the proportion of data blocks successfully delivered versus those lost; the data block transfer delay, which quantifies the time taken for a data block to be transferred from source to destination; and the data block delay jitter, which measures the variation in transfer delay experienced by different data blocks.
